title: Vehicle type approval

table.body:
Type approval is a process of making sure that vehicles meet European safety and environmental standards. 

There are different ways to approve a vehicle and the one you use depends on the vehicle you have.

## Help with type approval enquiries

Contact the Vehicle and Operator Services Agency (VOSA) If you need help or information about the:
 
- Individual Vehicle Approval (IVA) scheme
- Single Vehicle Approval (SVA) scheme
- Motorcycle Single Vehicle Approval (MSVA) scheme

$C
**VOSA Helpline:** 0300 123 9000  
**Email:** <enquiries@vosa.gov.uk>
$C

For any other type approval schemes, contact the Vehicle Certification Agency (VCA). 

$C
**VCA Customer Enquiries**
0117 952 4235
<enquiries@vca.gov.uk>
$C

*[VOSA]: Vehicle and Operator Services Agency
table.title: Overview

table.body:
Most motor vehicles and trailers used on the road need type approval.

You don't need type approval for:

- cars and light goods vehicles over 10 years old
- heavy goods vehicles over 25 years old  

If your vehicle needs type approval, you must send in proof of this when you apply to register it. If you don't, the Driver and Vehicle Licensing Agency (DVLA) won't register the vehicle.

%If your vehicle fails its approval tests, it can’t be [registered](/vehicle-registration "Register your vehicle").%
table.title: When you need type approval

table.body:
##Who can use the scheme?

You can use the Individual Vehicle Approval (IVA) scheme for vehicles that haven't been registered before in the UK and are:

- passenger cars
- light goods vehicles (under 3,500 kilograms)
- buses and coaches
- medium to heavy sized goods vehicles (more than 3,500 kilograms)
- trailers
- special purpose vehicles, like vehicles specially designed to hold a wheelchair

##Vehicle identification number

Your vehicle needs a [vehicle identification number](/vehicle-registration/vehicle-identification-number "Vehicle identification number") before having an IVA inspection. If it doesn’t have one, apply to your [Driver and Vehicle Licensing Agency (DVLA) local office.](http://www.dft.gov.uk/dvla/contactus/localoffices/findnear.aspx "Find your DVLA local office"){:rel="external"}

##Cost of the scheme 

You have to [pay a fee](inspection-fees "Inspection fees") for the Vehicle and Operator Services Agency (VOSA) to inspect your vehicle.

##Choosing a test station

Your vehicle will be inspected by VOSA at one of their approved test stations or Privately Owned Test Facilities (POTFs). You can choose which one.

$D
[Download list of IVA test stations and POTFs (PDF, 274KB)](http://www.dft.gov.uk/vosa/repository/CONT208011.pdf "List of IVA test stations and POTFs"){:rel="external"}
$D

##Basic and normal IVAs

A **basic IVA** involves a combination of visual inspection and specific tests (eg emissions tests) to make sure the vehicle complies with (meets) the necessary standards. You won't normally need to provide documentary evidence of compliance.

A **normal IVA** involves a more detailed inspection, vehicles have to comply with extra standards and you'll have to provide documentary evidence of compliance.

### Which IVA you can apply for

You can apply for a basic IVA if your vehicle is a passenger car or a light goods vehicle in the following categories:

- left hand drive vehicles
- personal imports
- amateur built vehicles (kit cars)
- rebuilt vehicles
- very low volume production vehicles
- ambulances
- motor caravans
- hearses
- armoured vehicles
- a vehicle manufactured using parts of a registered vehicle

^For help understanding these categories, download [VOSA’s guide to the IVA (PDF, 1.84MB)](http://www.businesslink.gov.uk/Transport_files/IVA_Information_Guide.pdf "Guide to the IVA: VOSA"){:rel="external"} - annex 1 and 2.^

In all other cases, you’ll have to apply for a normal IVA.

## Choosing the correct form

The IVA application form you fill in depends on the type of vehicle you have. Download application forms and guidance below.

###Passenger cars or light goods vehicles

$D
[Download IVA application form for passenger cars or light goods vehicles (DOC, 786KB)](http://www.businesslink.gov.uk/Transport_files/Application_for_IVA_M1_v4_0911.doc "IVA application form for passenger cars or light goods vehicles"){:rel="external"} 
[Download guidance on completing IVA application form for passenger cars or light goods vehicles (PDF, 64KB)](http://www.businesslink.gov.uk/Transport_files/IVA_1_M1_Guidance_Notes_0911.pdf "Guidance on completing IVA application form for passenger cars or light goods vehicles"){:rel="external"}
$D

###Buses or coaches

$D
[Download IVA application form for buses or coaches (DOC, 992KB)](http://www.businesslink.gov.uk/Transport_files/IVA_Application_for_M2_M3_Vehicles.doc "IVA application form for buses or coaches"){:rel="external"} 
[Download guidance on completing IVA application form for buses or coaches (PDF, 61KB)](http://www.businesslink.gov.uk/Transport_files/IVA_Application_Guidance_Notes.pdf "Guidance on completing IVA application form for buses or coaches"){:rel="external"}
[Download seat belt anchorage compliance (PDF, 843KB)](http://www.dft.gov.uk/vosa/repository/IVA%2019b.doc "Seat belt anchorage compliance and installation"){:rel="external"}
$D

###Lorries or large goods vehicles

$D
[Download IVA application form for lorries or large goods vehicles (DOC, 837KB)](http://www.businesslink.gov.uk/Transport_files/IVA_Application_for_N2N3_vehicles_0311.doc "IVA application form for lorries or large goods vehicles"){:rel="external"}
[Download guidance on completing IVA application form for lorries or large goods vehicles (PDF, 69KB)](http://www.businesslink.gov.uk/Transport_files/112_IVA1H_Application_Guidance_Notes_0511.pdf "Guidance on completing IVA application form for lorries and large goods vehicles"){:rel="external"}
$D

###Trailers

$D
[Download IVA application form for trailers (DOC, 387KB)](http://www.businesslink.gov.uk/Transport_files/IVA_Application_for_O104_vehicles_0411.doc "IVA application form for trailers"){:rel="external"} 
[Download guidance on IVA application form for trailers (PDF, 53KB)](http://www.businesslink.gov.uk/Transport_files/IVA_1T_Guidance_Notes_0311.pdf "Guidance on completing the IVA form for trailers"){:rel="external"}
$D

###Amateur built vehicles

If your vehicle is amateur built (eg a kit car), you must send an amateur built declaration along with your IVA application.

$D
[Download amateur built declaration (DOC, 509KB).](http://www.businesslink.gov.uk/Transport_files/119_IVA_Amateur_Built_Declaration1010.doc "IVA application form for amateur built vehicles"){:rel="external"}
$D

##What happens next 

VOSA will inspect your vehicle at the test location you've chosen and will issue an Individual Approval Certificate (IAC) if it passes. You’ll need to use this certificate when you register your vehicle.

##Appeal against a refusal

If your vehicle doesn't pass its inspection and you're not satisfied with the decision, you can appeal and have a re-examination carried out by an independent inspector. 

You must make your appeal within 14 days of the decision and you'll have to pay a fee. This will be refunded, either partially or fully, if your appeal is successful.

You mustn't modify the vehicle before the appeal inspection. 

You can appeal by downloading and filling in the IVA notice of appeal.

$D
[Download IVA notice of appeal (DOC, 139KB).](http://www.businesslink.gov.uk/Transport_files/121_IVA_Notice_of_Appeal_1110.doc "IVA notice of appeal: VOSA"){:rel="external"}
$D

For more information on appeals, see part 8 of VOSA's guide to the IVA, below.

##More information
VOSA has produced an in-depth guide to the IVA.

$D
[Download VOSA's guide to the IVA (PDF, 1.84MB)](http://www.businesslink.gov.uk/Transport_files/IVA_Information_Guide.pdf "Guide to the IVA: VOSA"){:rel="external"}
$D

*[IVAs]: Individual Vehicle Approvals
*[IVA]: Individual Vehicle Approval
*[VOSA]: Vehicle and Operator Services Agency
*[IAC]: Individual Approval Certificate
table.title: Individual Vehicle Approval

table.body:
##Who can use the scheme?

The Individual Vehicle Approval (IVA) scheme is replacing the Single Vehicle Approval (SVA) scheme. Any vehicle needing type approval can now use the IVA. 

For a limited time, you can choose to use the SVA instead for certain vehicles that haven't been registered before in the UK:

- special purpose vehicles, like wheelchair-accessible vehicles - up until 29 April 2012
- medium to heavy goods vehicles (over 3,500 kilograms) and trailers - up until 29 October 2012
 
After 29 October 2012, all vehicles needing type approval must use the IVA.

$D
[Download a guide to the differences between SVA and IVA for light goods vehicles (PDF, 294KB)](http://www.dft.gov.uk/vosa/repository/SVA%20to%20IVA%20Guide%20v1%20April%2011.pdf "Guide to the differences between SVA and IVA: VOSA"){:rel="external"}
$D

##Cost of the scheme

You have to [pay a fee](inspection-fees "Inspection fees") for the Vehicle and Operator Services Agency (VOSA) to inspect your vehicle.

##Choosing a test station

Your vehicle will be inspected by VOSA at one of their approved [test stations.](http://www.direct.gov.uk/en/Dl1/Directories/UsefulContactsByCategory/MotoringContacts/DG_069669 "Single Vehicle Approval test stations"){:rel="external"} You can choose which one.

##Standard or Enhanced?

You can apply for Standard Single Vehicle Approval (SVA) if your vehicle is a special purpose vehicle in the following categories:

- hearses
- motor caravans
- ambulances
- armoured vehicles

You’ll need to get Enhanced Single Vehicle Approval (ESVA) for:

- all other special purpose vehicles (including wheelchair accessible vehicles)
- medium to heavy goods vehicles
- trailers

## Sending in the application form

The application form is the same for both Standard and Enhanced Single Vehicle Approval.

$D
[Download SVA application form (DOC, 696KB)](http://www.dft.gov.uk/vosa/repository/Application%20for%20Ministers%20Approval%20Certificate%20for%20Vehicles%20(SVA%201).doc "SVA application form"){:rel="external"}
[Download guidance on completing SVA application form (PDF, 135KB)](http://www.dft.gov.uk/vosa/repository/SVA%201%20Guidance%20Notes.pdf "Guidance on completing the SVA form"){:rel="external"}
$D

##Enhanced Single Vehicle Approval (ESVA)

Your vehicle will be tested to make sure it complies with European Community (EC) type approval standards (or equivalent) for 10 key areas if:

- it needs Enhanced Single Vehicle Approval
- it’s a passenger vehicle
- it’s built from the dates shown in the table below 

###10 key areas tested

**Key area** | **Vehicle tested if built after this date**
- | -
Seat belt anchorages | 1 July 1991
Protective steering |  1 July 1991
Noise and silencers |  1 July 1991
Exhaust emissions | 1 January 1993
Brakes | 1 April 1995
Seat belt installations | 1 July 1997
CO2 / fuel consumption | 1 January 1997
Anti-theft device | 1 October 1998
Frontal impact protection | 1 October 2003
Side impact protection | 1 October 2003

### Ways to demonstrate compliance

There are different ways to prove your vehicle complies with the EC standards. For example, you can show that the vehicle:

- meets European approval standards (eg the vehicle has a type approval number)
- is the same specification as one that meets the standards (you can show this using a model report)

For full details on ways to demonstrate compliance, see part 3 of [VOSA’s guide to the SVA (PDF, 1.26MB)](http://www.dft.gov.uk/vosa/repository/A%20Guide%20to%20the%20Single%20Vehicle%20Approval%20Scheme.pdf "Guide to the SVA: VOSA"){:rel="external"}

###Model reports

One way of proving your vehicle is compliant is by demonstrating it’s the same specification as another vehicle (a ‘master vehicle’) that’s been proved compliant. You do this using a model report. 

If a model report has already been produced for your exact model of vehicle, you may be able to use it for a fee. VOSA has a list of model reports and their owners.

$D
[Download ‘VOSA list of model reports and their owners’ (PDF, 1.39MB)](http://www.vosa.gov.uk/vosacorp/publications/modelreports/modelreports.htm "Download list of model reports and their owners: VOSA"){:rel="external"}
$D

Otherwise, you’ll need to pay for your own laboratory tests to be carried out. 

$D
[Download ‘ESVA approved testing laboratories’ (PDF, 21KB)](http://www.dft.gov.uk/vosa/repository/Authorised%20Testing%20Laboratories%20Web%20Version.pdf "ESVA approved testing laboratories: VOSA"){:rel="external"}
$D

For more information on model reports, see part 8 of [VOSA’s guide to the SVA (PDF, 1.26MB)](http://www.dft.gov.uk/vosa/repository/A%20Guide%20to%20the%20Single%20Vehicle%20Approval%20Scheme.pdf "Guide to the SVA: VOSA"){:rel="external"}

##What happens next?
Vehicles that pass an SVA inspection are issued with a 'Minister’s Approval Certificate' (MAC).

##More information
VOSA has produced an in-depth guide to the SVA.

$D
[Download VOSA's guide to the SVA (PDF, 1.26MB)](http://www.dft.gov.uk/vosa/repository/A%20Guide%20to%20the%20Single%20Vehicle%20Approval%20Scheme.pdf "Guide to the SVA: VOSA"){:rel="external"}
$D

*[SVA]: Single Vehicle Approval
*[ESVA]: Enhanced Single Vehicle Approval
*[IVA]: Individual Vehicle Approval
*[EC]: European Community
*[VOSA]: Vehicle and Operator Services Agency
table.title: Single Vehicle Approval

table.body:
##When you must use the scheme

To register your motorcycle, 3-wheeled or light 4-wheeled vehicle, it must:

-  comply with European Community Whole Vehicle Type Approval (ECWVTA)
- have a Certificate of Conformity (CoC) to prove this

If it doesn’t have a Certificate of Conformity, it must be inspected under the Motorcycle Single Vehicle Approval (MSVA) scheme. 

You must also use the MSVA scheme if your vehicle has been radically altered or built using a mixture of parts from previously registered vehicles. For example:

- amateur built vehicles
- rebuilt vehicles
- vehicles converted to a different wheelplan

## Eligibility for MSVA

You can use the MSVA scheme for vehicles that:

- are under 10 years old
- haven't been registered before in the UK
- don’t have ECWVTA

The following types of vehicle are eligible:

- 2-wheeled mopeds
- 3-wheeled mopeds
- light quadricycles
- solo motorcycles
- motorcycle combinations
- motor tricycles
- heavy quadricycles

These vehicle types are defined in appendix 1 of the MSVA guide, produced by the Vehicle and Operator Services Agency (VOSA).

$D
[Download VOSA’s guide to the MSVA (PDF, 379KB)](http://www.dft.gov.uk/vosa/repository/MSVA%20Guide%20Jan%202011.pdf "Guide to the MSVA: VOSA"){:rel="external"}
$D

## Partial MSVA

If you have a Certificate of Conformity (CoC), it will say which side of the road and which speedometer units your vehicle is equipped for. 

If your vehicle isn’t equipped for use in Great Britain, you must modify it. It will then need a Partial MSVA to check the following items:

- headlamp dipped beam pattern - this checks the headlamp is suitable for driving on the left
- speedometer - the speed must be shown in miles per hour (mph) or dual mph and kilometres per hour
- mirror location - on mopeds fitted with a single mirror, the mirror must be fitted to offside (right) of the vehicle

VOSA has answers to frequently asked questions about the Partial MSVA.

$D
[Download 'Partial MSVA: frequently asked questions' (22KB, PDF)](http://www.dft.gov.uk/vosa/repository/MSVA%20Partial%20inspection%20FAQ.pdf "Partial MSVA: frequently asked questions"){:rel="external"}
$D

##Vehicle identification number

Your vehicle needs a [vehicle identification number](/vehicle-registration/vehicle-identification-number "Vehicle identification number") before having an MSVA inspection. If it doesn’t have one, apply to your [Driver and Vehicle Licensing Agency (DVLA) local office.](http://www.dft.gov.uk/dvla/contactus/localoffices/findnear.aspx "Find your DVLA local office"){:rel="external"}

##Cost of the scheme 

You have to [pay a fee](inspection-fees "Inspection fees") for VOSA to inspect your vehicle.

##Choosing a test station

Your vehicle will be inspected by VOSA at one of their approved [test stations.](http://www.direct.gov.uk/en/Dl1/Directories/UsefulContactsByCategory/MotoringContacts/DG_069952 "Motorcycle Single Vehicle Approval test stations"){:rel="external"} You can choose which one.

## Sending in the application form

$D
[Download MSVA application form (DOC, 329KB)](http://www.dft.gov.uk/vosa/repository/Application%20for%20Ministers%20Approval%20Certificate%20for%20Vehicles%20(MSVA%201).doc "MSVA application form"){:rel="external"}
$D

$D
[Download Partial MSVA application form (DOC, 178KB)](http://www.dft.gov.uk/vosa/repository/Motorcycle%20Single%20Vehicle%20Approval%20-%20PMSVA%201.doc "Partial MSVA application form"){:rel="external"}
$D

##What happens next 

VOSA will inspect your vehicle at the test station you've chosen and issue a Minister's Approval Certificate (MAC) if it passes. You’ll need to use this certificate when you register your vehicle.

## Appeals

If your vehicle fails MSVA, you can appeal for a re-test within 14 days of the original decision. You'll have to pay a fee, which will be refunded if the appeal is successful. [Contact VOSA](overview "Overview") to find out how to do this. 

##More information
VOSA has produced an in-depth guide to the MSVA.

$D
[Download VOSA’s guide to the MSVA (PDF, 379KB)](http://www.dft.gov.uk/vosa/repository/MSVA%20Guide%20Jan%202011.pdf "Guide to the MSVA: VOSA"){:rel="external"}
$D

*[VOSA]: Vehicle and Operator Services Agency
*[IAC]: Individual Approval Certificate 
*[ECWVTA]: European Community Whole Vehicle Type Approval
*[CoC]: Certificate of Conformity
*[MSVA]: Motorcycle Single Vehicle Approval
table.title: Motorcycle Single Vehicle Approval

table.body:
You can only use the Individual Vehicle Approval (IVA) and Single Vehicle Approval (SVA) schemes for vehicles that **haven't** been registered before in the UK. 

If you need to prove the compliance of a vehicle that's already registered, you must use use the voluntary version of these schemes.

$E
**Example:** A taxi licensing authority may need evidence of compliance if your vehicle has been modified since it was originally registered.
$E

##Choosing a scheme

The scheme you can use depends on your vehicle and the date you apply for the scheme. 

The criteria are the same for the voluntary or compulsory version of the schemes:

- find out the criteria for using [voluntary or compulsory IVA](individual-vehicle-approval "Individual Vehicle Approval")
- find out the criteria for using [voluntary or compulsory SVA](single-vehicle-approval "Single Vehicle Approval") 

##Cost of the schemes

You have to [pay a fee](inspection-fees "Inspection fees") for the Vehicle and Operator Services Agency (VOSA) to inspect your vehicle. The voluntary versions of the schemes cost the same, except that VAT is payable. 

##How to apply for the voluntary IVA

To apply for the voluntary IVA, use the same forms as for the [compulsory version of the scheme](individual-vehicle-approval "Individual Vehicle Approval").

VOSA has produced guidance on completing the form for passenger cars and light goods vehicles (less than 3,500 kilograms).

$D
[Download 'Guidance on completing Voluntary Individual Vehicle Approval application form' (PDF, 60KB)](http://www.businesslink.gov.uk/Transport_files/VIVA_1_Guidance_Notes_0711.pdf "Guidance on completing Voluntary Individual Vehicle Approval application form"){:rel="external"}
$D

##How to apply for the voluntary SVA

To apply for the voluntary SVA, download the form below.

$D
[Download 'Voluntary SVA 1 application form' (VSVA 1) (DOC, 757KB)](http://www.dft.gov.uk/vosa/repository/Application%20for%20a%20Voluntary%20Single%20Vehicle%20Approval%20Examination%20(VSVA%201).doc "Voluntary SVA 1 application form"){:rel="external"}
$D

##What happens next?

VOSA will carry out an inspection of the vehicle. If it passes, you'll be given a 'Confirmation of Compliance' notification (not an approval certificate).

##Find out more

VOSA has produced in-depth guides to the IVA and SVA. Each guide has information about the voluntary versions of the schemes.

$D
[Download VOSA's in-depth guide to the SVA (PDF, 1.26MB)](http://www.dft.gov.uk/vosa/repository/A%20Guide%20to%20the%20Single%20Vehicle%20Approval%20Scheme.pdf "Guide to the SVA: VOSA"){:rel="external"}
[Download VOSA's in-depth guide to the IVA (PDF, 1.84MB)](http://www.businesslink.gov.uk/Transport_files/IVA_Information_Guide.pdf "Guide to the IVA: VOSA"){:rel="external"}
$D

*[SVA]: Single Vehicle Approval
*[IVA]: Individual Vehicle Approval
*[VOSA]: Vehicle and Operator Services Agency
*[VAT]: Value Added Tax
table.title: Voluntary approval

table.body:
You have to pay a fee for the Vehicle and Operator Services Agency (VOSA) to inspect your vehicle. 

The cost depends on the type of inspection and the category of your vehicle. 

##Common categories of vehicle

Common categories include:

- M1 - passenger vehicles (no more than 8 seats)
- N1 - small goods vehicle (less than 3,500 kilograms)

For a full list of categories, see annex 1 of [VOSA’s guide to the IVA (PDF, 1.84MB).](http://www.businesslink.gov.uk/Transport_files/IVA_Information_Guide.pdf "Guide to the IVA: VOSA"){:rel="external"}

##Common classes of vehicle 

Some common classes of vehicles include:

- class A - amateur built M1 or N1 vehicles
- class P - personal import of M1 or N1 vehicles
- class S - rebuilt M1 or N1 vehicles
- class C - M1 or N1 vehicles manufactured using parts of registered vehicles

For a full list of classes, see annex 2 of [VOSA’s guide to the IVA (PDF, 1.84MB).](http://www.businesslink.gov.uk/Transport_files/IVA_Information_Guide.pdf "Guide to the IVA: VOSA"){:rel="external"}

##Individual Vehicle Approval (IVA)

The tables below cover fees for passenger cars (M1) only. 

**Statutory** | **Inspection** | **Re-inspection**
- | -
Basic (Classes A, C, S) | £450 | £90
Basic (Classes L, M, N, P) | £199 | £40
Normal | £199 | £40

**Voluntary** | **Inspection** | **Re-inspection**
- | -
Basic (Classes A, C, S) | £450 + VAT | £90 + VAT
Basic (Classes L, M, N, P) | £199 + VAT | £40 + VAT
Normal | £199 + VAT | £40 + VAT

For a full list of IVA fees, including large passenger vehicles, goods vehicles and trailers, see pages 1 and 2 of ['IVA inspection fees' (PDF, 294KB).](http://www.businesslink.gov.uk/Transport_files/108_IVA_Inspection_Fees_1111.pdf "IVA inspection fees"){:rel="external"}

##Single Vehicle Approval (SVA)

For a full list of SVA fees, see pages 3 and 4 of ['IVA inspection fees' (PDF, 294KB).](http://www.businesslink.gov.uk/Transport_files/108_IVA_Inspection_Fees_1111.pdf "IVA inspection fees"){:rel="external"}

##Motorcycle Single Vehicle Approval (MSVA)

For a full list of MSVA fees, see page 4 of ['IVA inspection fees' (PDF, 294KB).](http://www.businesslink.gov.uk/Transport_files/108_IVA_Inspection_Fees_1111.pdf "IVA inspection fees"){:rel="external"}

*[VOSA]: Vehicle and Operator Services Agency
*[IVA]: Individual Vehicle Approval
*[SVA]: Single Vehicle Approval
*[MSVA]: Motorcycle Single Vehicle Approval
